pros: You will meet a great group of new people.
cons: The long work hours, combined with the staff that don't see you as volunteers and more as hourly workers.

review_title: Professional but not work life focused
pros: High quality of professionalism and delivers high quality trails and conservation nationally.
cons: Work culture is between 40-60 hours a week with no overtime. Benefits aren't very good, no retirement match, healthcare costs a ton, and no paid leave if you have a kid. Good place to work if you're 18-23 but if you're a professional adult with a family, you wont feel valued.

pros: It’s so dysfunctional that people get away with things.
cons: It’s so dysfunctional that nothing gets done. The new guy they hired for culture doesn’t really care about the culture or diversity.

pros: - Travel - References - Field Experience
cons: - Low Pay - Unsafe work environment - High Burnout

review_title: Great foot in the door environmental experience
job_title: Crew Member in Boulder Creek, CA
pros: Safety prioritized, great community, scenic work sites
cons: Logistics like housing can be a bit hectic

pros: Great organization to provide applicable skills for those wanting to dive into a professional outdoor job/career/market
cons: You get what you want out of it.

pros:
-Get to work outside and connect with local land management agencies 
-Good pathway into natural resources 
- Hands on experience
cons:
-Not very good pay 
-They try to avoid giving you benefits or time off even though your a salary 
-THEY WILL OVERWORK YOU and not compensate in return and wait till you burn out to just replace you. They expect a lot considering what they offer in return. 
-Un supportive with client relations or issues. 
-Unprofessional with HR related issues.

pros: Equips individuals with an adequate knowledge base surrounding trails and conservation
cons: At the end of the day, it's more about the numbers than the member experience.

review_title: Great gap year job experience, challenging but rewarding
pros: -Get to spend time in beautiful natural areas -Develop environmental restoration skills
cons: -Base camp is remote and hard to get into town

pros: Experience in leadership Learning flexibility Thinking on your feet Improved social skills
cons: Lack of personal space and time Unknowledgable staff

review_title: Best only for high school graduates
job_title: Crew Member in Corpus Christi, TX
pros: A good way to get experience if you have none and you get a small education award
cons:
The pay is low. I'd only recommend doing it if you've recently got out of high school, you don't have much expenses yet, and you have zero experience. There are a good amount of jobs that do the same work as ACE but they pay you a more fair wage than a stipend. ACE is that kind of company that can bid lower for contracts because they take advantage of paying less for volunteers. They are pretty comfortable financially. ACE makes you pride yourself in that you're being a good public servant. 

Work life and Housing are a wild card and it all depends on who ends up on your crew. ACE tend to attract a certain demographic who are more progressive and left-leaning, are hippies, drug users, and once in a while troublemakers. On my crew, one of the members punched someone out of the blue and he was fired but then he became homeless and hung around on the streets. One day someone forgot to lock the door before hitch and the project manager and director found him in housing during a check up. According to my crew leaders, incidents like this happen every now and then. The director didn't handle the situation very well.

I was a part of a invasive species crew and we learned to use a chainsaw and spray herbicide but the work entirely depended on what contracts your crew got so I ended up doing mostly chainsaw work and no herbicide work. The chainsaw work was mostly clearing fence lines and boundary lines and nothing to do with controlling invasive species. One project all we did was take down two prairie chicken pens and that was it. In my experience, it was simply glorified yard work.

pros: The entry-level staff and volunteers really believe in the mission.
cons: The CEO is shady, the leadership team values growth at the expense of the people, the members are not cared for appropriately.

job_title: Division Support Specialist in Flagstaff, AZ
pros: Flexible and remote work options. Get to travel to sites.
cons: Slow to adopt organization wide change. People are underpaid. Bad family and maternity/paternity leave policy/benefits.

job_title: Lands and Realty Intern  in Palm Springs, CA
pros: An excellent place to start and develop a career in the environmental industry. Great experience, just be prepared to not love your job.
cons: Mundane office tasks, especially if you do not advocate for yourself.

job_title: Corps Member in South Lake Tahoe, CA
pros: chainsaws are so sick fr
cons: work hard and little pay

pros: Provides service opportunities for youth
cons: Volunteers transition out every 3 to 6 months

pros: Great people and sense of accomplishment
cons: Low pay not keeping up with inflation- nonprofit sector

pros: culture, schedule, location, people, housing, food
cons: pay, heat, not much besides that

pros: Rewarding work with the opportunity to work in amazing places.
cons: Inconsistent schedule due to the demands of managing crews in the field.

pros: My time at ACE was...fine. Experiences very tied to the people you are paired with, which heavily varies. Some people who do ACE are great and some of the best people I've ever met. But when you have a great crew, it's a lot of fun.
cons: Some of the downsides were 1) huge lack of communication and just lack of common sense from ACE management and 2) if you're stuck with a bad crew, you're stuck with them for a bit. Also, last year at least, people were not always the most covid safe or cleanly.

job_title: Graduate Student in Santa Barbara, CA
pros: Foster youth interested in green careers
cons: Long hours with most positions

pros: Employees develop their physical strength and stamina from swinging pick-mattocks and hiking with heavy packs on their backs for most of the day. Workers also practice patience by performing repetitive tasks that they may learn to enjoy with productivity. The leaders put effort in sharing knowledge they have about species identification and human responses to temperature extremes and lack of water or salt. Everyone has the opportunity to develop a stronger relationship with nature.
cons: I did not agree with removing invasive species- especially with herbicide like RoundUp. Work variety reduces during the cold months.

pros: Caring people, friendly atmosphere, rewarding work.
cons: The staff are pretty homogenous in the way they look and act. There are communication failures and sometimes impossible asks. The low pay makes the hard work difficult to justify.

pros: Great way to get foot in conservation field and gain valuable experience.
cons: You won't be picking your assignments, but that's not too bad.

job_title: Associate Director of Member Resources in Sacramento, CA
pros: Excellent Team Work Ethic and Support
cons: N/A N/A N/A N/A N/A N/A

pros: Meaningful work, learn a lot of technical skills when in the field. Office work is computer heavy.
cons: Focus on partner expectations and not member experience. AmeriCorps so expect low living allowance. Pretty standard

review_title: Awful management with no work life balance
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: ACE attracts a lot of interesting and fun members. Good health benefits.
cons: Bad pay. Awful management e.g. Julia Parish and Sarah Miggins. Poor work life balance. Micromanaging, harassment and bullying (from senior staff) is a big problem amongst staff. They make promises on hiring that turn out to be untrue. No/limited career progression.

review_title: Must be willing to work hard
pros: You meet some amazing people, but the work is not always the most glamorous and can be thankless.
cons: You're not home often but that is something they make clear during the interview process

review_title: Great Experience! Fun and hard work
pros: field experience, team, supportive staff
cons: some provided housing was nicer than others

pros: Good work and good coworkers
cons: Poorly run, overworked, toxic workplace

pros: Great work with great people
cons: Terrible office organization. They WILL hang you out to dry if you're a Corp member.

review_title: Awesome opportunity to learn new concepts
pros: Education and opportunities allow entry level candidates opportunities to grow as a professional
cons: The pay isn't the best

pros: Fun to work in nature
cons: somewhat isolating during off season

pros: Travel throughout Southwest & meet new folks
cons: Management was awful, and they don't feed you much of anything

review_title: Good work experience for young people
pros: The housing and most of your food is paid for with this job
cons: The work can be tough and you're often camping near the work site

pros: I have the pleasure of leading others in conservation efforts in amazing locations.
cons: It is difficult to receive in-person training while using Covid-19 precautions.

review_title: Great as a Corps Members, Not so much as Staff.
pros:
As a corps member you:
Get to travel all over the region you are stationed in to many amazing parks and public lands.
Make friends that will last a lifetime.
Get field experience and potentially your foot in the door for conservation jobs.
Have housing provided.
cons:
Corps Member stipend is low.
Upper management does not communicate well with lower management and corps members. Lots of miss-communication or non at all.
There are upper management that are very disconnected from the members. Many members never know or met the majority of the staff.
If you work in the office you will be lucky to have time off. They claim it is "flexible" which equates to odd hours, weekends, and multiple weeks without two days off in a row.
Lots of big promises to corps members about professional development that never happen.
Again big disconnect - some corps members get more attention than others while some long-time members never get advanced trainings even though they've been there a year or so.
Mentality of "fighting fires" instead of preventing them.
Mostly talk and little action.
Expected to do multiple people's jobs at little pay.
Understaffed with high turn over rate. Interview process can take weeks or months. When people leave and give notice management doesn't start hiring until they already left.

job_title: Conservation Corps Member in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Lots of cool projects in restoration and trail maintenance
cons: Poor housing arrangements, lack of consistency in scheduling

pros:
As an AmeriCorps member you will see beautiful places and meet wonderful people
If you are lucky you will get WFA trained along with a specific skills training
As staff you can work independently and if you don’t screw up no one will manage you (unless you are a woman)
cons:
Housing is horrific and can be dangerous
Staff are promised skills training and development but then they don’t receive any
Little to no diversity! Most AmeriCorps members are young white males and hiring personnel seem to want to keep it that way
Men with less knowledge and experience are given promotions over women with ambition and skills
If you take any time off at all you are considered less worthy for promotions
Management does a poor job of supporting some field crews
Sexual harassment
Incestuous, gossip-y work environment
Sometimes it is hard to say whether the mission is conservation or just making money
It is almost mandatory that employees can not have personal lives because they expect you to work constantly

pros: Good People, Fun projects, Free food
cons: Horrible Management, Racism, Terrible living conditions, Management made me quit, Coworkers allowed to harm mental health

pros: You get to work in beautiful places and alongside dedicated volunteers ... but you could get that at any other similar organization
cons:
An extremely misogynistic work environment at the management level. They expect you to work more than 40 hours but frown upon you for keeping a track of all those hours. There is no overtime pay. every few weeks they just ask you to take a day or two off for all the extra time you've accumulated. There is a expected culture of overworking and underpaying at least the female employees.

 Extremely terrible communication  in the workplace which consists of a complete lack of communication or miscommunication. 

They hire you at a low salary promising career and skill development but as soon as you sign the contract, career development is out the window. 

There is no real HR department if anyone should have any issues. 

I was beyond miserable working for this organization. They definitely exploit the enthusiasm and naivete of the young.

pros: Seeing some of the most beautiful sights as you travel for work. 3-7 days off in a row after 5 to 12 days of work.
cons: Unprofessional crew leaders, sloppy office workers who do not take the interns concerns very seriously. I have witnessed numerous crew leaders and a few from office doing drugs on and off job. 2nd time joining ace i had my good friend from home join me, and office purposely gave us opposite projects out of states the entire time. Did not see him once. 12 people in one small bedroom. My bed being next to a community bathroom door so i would smell everything. Little to no credit given to employees during "evaluation" phone call towards end of stay, more like an office worker calling from flag to tell you what you can do better etc.

review_title: Stay Away from the PCT program and this organization in General
pros: GO work for an organization that cares about you. SIgned up for the PCT 2016 crew and it was a miserable experience. The main goal of the PCT crew is to milk every drop of sweat they can out of you at the lowest possible price. You will be worked to the bone and it is not worth it. If you want to pursue a career in trail work this would help you do that, or sign up for the normal program and that would do the same and be a much more enjoyable experience.
cons: The PCT crew receives half the pay that normal 900 hr ace CA members receive but works significantly more hours. You will be placed in the deep south of CA  in the hot desert. You will not be backcountry camping or anywhere cool on the trail you will be rebuilding the destroyed sections. Do the normal 900 program if you have to but stay away from this.

pros: The individual people doing the hands-on daily work are some of the most caring, compassionate, giving people I have ever had the pleasure of working with.
cons: The pressure to produce is unbearable. The more you give the harder you are pushed to give more. There is no appreciation for a job well done and you are treated as a resource, not a person. No employee should ever be told "just be thankful that you have a job:

review_title: My experience was educational and eye opening.
pros: You'll meet people that you will be amazing friends with for most of your term, and you'll experience so much in such a short time it'll be mind boggling. It's 6-3 months that feels like two months.
cons:
You know all those friends you've made, yeah they are going to leave before you do. Leaving you behind... As an empty shell waiting for the end of your term. 
But that's all fine if you keep in touch .

review_title: Great ideology at its heart, but slow down expansion and tighten up standards to exisiting branches
pros: Work in some amazing locations, learn about conservation and the outdoors, meet some fantastic people, feel good about yourself.
cons: Not enough support staff, a bit cheap when it comes to investing money, lack of clear long-term direction for the company and staff.  Expects 100%, but can treat members like they are a commodity.

pros: You meet some wonderful, unique people and get to work in very beautiful areas. You may even learn a thing or two about conservation.
cons: The pay is terrible, housing is dangerous if you have anything valuable, and the full time employees never seem to know what is going on.

review_title: Without a doubt a good experience for anyone looking to be in an outdoor job.
pros: Outdoors, mentorship, experiential learning, team building, travel, meeting new people, build skills, trail building, chainsaw, new experiences, new places, food, education award through americorps, Camping, free housing, food on project...frankly just go.
cons: Long periods away from home base, sometimes work in hard conditions hot, cold or damp, in secluded areas without contact to emergency services sometimes, occasionally no privacy from team mates

review_title: Great way to gain experience - fast paced company
pros: It is a great company to gain experience fast. If you show the aptitude they will give you plenty to do. The staff are friendly as easy to get along with.
cons: You have to get used to the long hours and after hours calls. It is easy to gain responsibility and develop into leadership roles, but that often comes at of your work-life balance. If you are willing to work hard to get ahead this is the place for you.

review_title: Challenging and rewarding with great crews
pros:
working outdoors in beautiful locations
provided housing full time and food while on a crew
free weekends in wilderness land meant hiking, swimming, exploring
training for tasks
if your education is in the field then you have great references, networks, and opportunities for growth within ACE
recently expanded, now have three offices working on a fourth. was a western US org and now it's national
cons: some members believed the work hard/ party hard motto, which distracted them from the task at hand

pros: Got to travel to great places around the SouthWest
cons: Management has no idea what they're doing; housing they provide is disgusting and total chaos; they claim to feed you on hitch, but you get 2 slices of packaged meat, and the "fresh" fruit is gone by day 3; everyone has an attitude; they threaten to blacklist you from ever having another government job if you decide to quit before your volunteer time is over

pros: ACE offers a fast-paced environment with varied work. There are numerous opportunities to travel. Staff welcome innovative approaches to problem solving. Fantastic office locations, flexible work hours.
cons: Flexible work hours is a positive but the flip-side is that work goes home with you, in that sense the hours can be quite extended, and weekend work common.

review_title: A company that is growing too fast for its own good.
job_title: Professional Development Intern in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Very friendly atmosphere. Good for networking. You work in beautiful locations. The work is also rather varied so you get experience with many jobs.
cons: Very disorganized. They seem to be growing faster than they can keep up with organization. This leads to a lot of problems.

review_title: Great organization to work for to grow and develop technical and leadership skills, challenging and demanding work
pros: Great organization for developing leadership, management, and logistical skills. Plenty of opportunity for promotion if you work hard for it. Young organization that is growing, and has potential for you to make it your own.
cons: Not much work/life balance. Often worked weekends or on-call. Unsteady work schedule, making it difficult to plan for personal life events.

pros: Learn hands on techniques and receive training in a variety of conservation based projects. Work side by side with agencies such as National Park Service, Bureau of Land Management, and US Forest Service. Inclusive environment builds on foundation of trust within each crew. Get to work outside in a beautiful location!
cons: May have to endure harsh elements on project sites, group housing sometimes feels over-crowded.

pros: Excellent benefits and further education opportunities. Great training ground for students and a great place to expand your professional network.
cons: Mediocre management. Managers need to be trained in management and not just the technical aspects of the job. People take things personally - it is business!

review_title: Work life balance is tough but coworkers are tops
pros: Work culture is great, pay is better, benefits are decent too, locations are great, mission is top notch. Really like ACE.
cons: promotion not based on merit, based on seniority.

pros: You meet some pretty amazing people along the way.
cons: ACE and the PCTA treat crew members like cattle. They seem to forget people are volunteering their time for 200 dollars every two weeks. They promote themselves as selfless environmentalists. The truth is it's all about the money for them.

pros:
Great people
Great work 
Beautiful views
Very active
Free housing
cons:
Pay is not great but you're a volunteer
Not really a con but the work schedule either 8 days on (straight) 6 days off or 4 days on 4 days off. Need to be flexible

pros: Fast paced growing nonprofit with plenty of opportunity to grow and develop yourself as a young nonprofit professional. Must love outdoors and to travel.
cons: Standard cons in the nonprofit world, overworked and underpaid. However, ACE offers a flexible schedule and you work with a highly competent and passionate team. This is hard to find in life.

job_title: Senior Business Consultant in Salem, VA
pros: Good benefits. Lots of room for advancement. A lot of good people to work with and collaborate with. Secure employment if you're in a big city.
cons: Care more about the business than the peeps

pros: You get to work outside, meet a lot of great people, and travel the south west.
cons: The office is very unorganized; office members are unapproachable. No one replies to emails, which is unacceptable. To keep this organization professional and flowing smoothly, more people should be hired.

review_title: Great experience for a new employee
job_title: Business Development Manager in Chicago, IL
pros: Terrific people, flexible work schedules, senior leadership that made themselves accessible and easy to work with
cons: Employee on-boarding experience was a bit of a challenge as I was new to the field and nobody really understood how to acclimate me into the company.

pros: Super fun, great people, free food on projects! This is definitely worth a 3-6 month commitment if you're looking for an adventure and learn more about conservation.
cons: Pay is super low, but as an AmeriCorps position I knew what I was signing up for.

review_title: Good if you like the vagabond lifestyle
pros: Great way to explore the country, get dirty and feel good while doing it
cons: Long hours, sun damage, overuse of certain muscle groups

pros: Personal growth and lifelong friendships gained.
cons: I did an internship through AmeriCorps. After finishing ACE, I felt like I had not gained experience to help further a career in environmental conservation. More professional development would be helpful.

review_title: Met lots of people, great place to work.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros: Long hours, hard work, sometimes primitive camping for weeks at a time. Met lots of people. Felt good doing conservation work.
cons: Long hours, hard work, sometimes primitive camping for weeks at a time.

pros: adventurous position, lots of learning and being challenged, interesting people
cons: too many employees for a small office staff made me feel like a number

review_title: Great job for anyone looking to take some time before entering into an environmental career

pros: Big company that deals with a lot of people, with alot of experience on b2c

great work culture

Bonus benefits to employers example referral bonus, bring your buddy bonus, medical benefits
Better insurance provison

pros: Decent hours and management would be relatively reasonable
cons: Not always easy to take your PTO, but as long as they had notice, no problem

pros: Pay is decent for starting out to pay bills.
cons: No advancement into management. You pretty much remain in the same position for years.

pros: Good people to work with
cons: The pay is way too low for the work you have to do. And there's no benefits

pros:
Amazing 3 month experience
Get to travel all over California
Time off at weekends

pros: great environment to work in and a great experience gained.
cons: I have no complaints about this company.

pros: Got to work outside in the wilderness, gained valuable experience

pros: Housing, allowance, weekends off mostly, a nice group of nice people.

pros: Get to work with seasoned BLMers on big time projects

pros: Great learning experience.Great growth opportunity.Management is approachable and helpful.

pros: You must join it,Its nice to work over there
cons: Too much pressure of work from team leaders.

pros: Ok could've been a little better

pros: Easy environment, good management, good compensation

pros: Good benefits and work life balance

pros: Great work environment for employees

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
